net.happybrackets.core.scheduling

Interface Clock.ClockTickListener

  • Enclosing class:
    Clock

    public static interface Clock.ClockTickListener
    ClockTick interface for receiving clock Tick events
    The clockTick(double, Clock) receives the scheduled event and is usually represented as a Lambda. For example: 
         testclock1.addClockTickListener(new Clock.ClockTickListener() {
      @Override
            public void clockTick(double offset, Clock clock) {

            }
        });
    is generally represented as: 
         testclock1.addClockTickListener((offset, clock) - > {

     });

    It is also possible to connect the one Clock.ClockTickListener to more than one clock. For example: 
     Clock testclock1 = new Clock(100);
 Clock testclock2 = new Clock(37);

 Clock.ClockTickListener clockTickListener = (offset, clock) - > {
     double clock_interval = clock.getClockInterval();
     long num_ticks =  clock.getNumberTicks();

     System.out.println("Clock interval " + clock_interval + " has had " + num_ticks + " ticks");
 };

 // Now add listener to both clocks
 testclock1.addClockTickListener(clockTickListener);
 testclock2.addClockTickListener(clockTickListener);

 testclock1.start();
 testclock2.start();

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Abstract Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      void clockTick(double offset, Clock clock)
      Event occurs when clock tick occurs.

    • Method Detail

      • clockTick

        void clockTick(double offset,
               Clock clock)
        Event occurs when clock tick occurs. The offset parameter indicates how far of the exact time in milliseconds the event occurred, while the clock is the clock that triggered the event. 
         testclock1.addClockTickListener((offset, clock) - > {

 });
        Parameters:
        offset - the number of milliseconds we are off the tick. Positive number is late, negative is early
        clock - the clock object sending the message
